availability.p: Indiana University provides the information contained on this web site for non-commercial, personal, or research use only. All other use, including but not limited to commercial or scholarly reproductions, redistribution, publication or transmission, whether by electronic means or otherwise, without prior written permission of the copyright holder is strictly prohibited.

imprint.publisher: Indiana University Law School Alumni Association

editorialDecl.p: This electronic text file was created by Optical Character Recognition (OCR), and has been encoded and edited using the recommendations for Level 4 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines for Best Encoding Practices. Digital facsimiles are also provided.

The following features will not be encoded though they are present in the printed text: page breaks, column breaks and article continuations. The latter two do not require faithful representation since facsimiles are provided, and article continuations and column breaks are disruptive to online reading. The page breaks are ommitted since they are complicated by article continuations. The newsletter is no more than a 4-8 pages long so we'll be providing facsimile acess starting on page 1 and from figures contained within the text.

projectDesc.p: The Maurer School of Law, Indiana University, Bloomington, is providing online access to its alumni newsletter, The I Witness, published from 1959-1968, which presents news stories about the law school, its faculty and alumni. .

langUsage.language: The I-Witness contains primarily English-language content.

div.bibl: Indiana University Law School Alumni Association. The I Witness. 1 May 1959. Bloomington, Indiana.
div.p: Published by the Alumni Association of the School of Law of Indiana University. Inquiries should be addressed to the Editor, G17 Union Building, Bloomington, Indiana.

div.head: A Message From Dean Wallace
div.opener: To the Alumni of Indiana University School of Law:
div.p: It is a pleasure to greet all of you in this first issue of the news bulletin, The I-Witness, sponsored by the Alumni Association of the Law School. Both Divisions of the school continue their successful operation, and when any of you are either in Indianapolis or Bloomington, we hope that you will take time to visit us so that we may have the opportunity of renewing old acquaintance. It is our sincere desire by this publication to keep you in closer touch with Indiana University, and its School of Law. With warmest regards to all of you, I am

div.head: EDITORIAL
div.p: Greetings! This issue launches The I-Witness on what we hope will be a long and successful career of service to our alumni. It is designed to keep you abreast of the news concerning your classmates and friends in the Law School, and to supply information about the current activities, development and progress of the School itself.

We plan to tell you about everything of interest that is happening in both the Bloomington and Indianapolis Divisions, including details of the serious and important work being done, and also some accounts of the lighter moments which relieve the tensions of constant study.

It is our aim to include an abundance of news concerning our alumni-their present whereabouts, jobs, political offices, types of work they are doing, and even their thoughts about the proper function of the Law School and the needs and interests of the legal profession.
For this we must depend upon you- send the news concerning yourself or your reticent friends to Mr. Richard Quaintance, Assistant Dean, School of Law, Bloomington, Indiana, for future issues.
Suggestions for improvement of the contents or format of the paper will be welcomed heartily.

div.head: School Of Law Alumni Banquet Honoring John S. Hastings To Be Held June 7; Alumni, Wives Urged To Attend
div.p: The annual School of Law Alumni reception and banquet will be held on Sunday afternoon,June 7, 1959 in Alumni Hall. The reception will begin at 4:30, the banquet at 5:30. The cost of the dinner will be $3.00 per person and wives are cordially invited. Reservation forms will be sent out by the Alumni Association. Ample housing facilities will be available.

The program will honor Judge John S. Hastings, '24, retiring presirent of the I.U. Board of Trustees. Mr.Willis Hickam '18 will deliver the principal address and the portrait of Judge Hastings, a gift of the alumni to the law school, will be unveiled.

As in prior years the graduating seniors will be honored guests. In addition several classes are planning reunions and special tables are being reserved for those classes. Class members are asked to contact the following chairmen concerning reunion plans.

list.item: Walter G. Mead, Mitchell & Huckelberry Building, Salem, Indiana.
George W. Henley, 100 1/2 South College Avenue, Bloomington, Indiana.
Marshall Williams, 2845 North Pennsylvania St., Indianapolis, Indiana.
Ray C. Thomas, 504 Broadway, Gary, Indiana.
John E. Fell, Armstrong-Landon Building, Kokomo, Indiana.
Philip E. Byron, First National Bank Building, Elkhart, Indiana.
Robert F. McCrea, 700 S. Jordan, Bloomington, Indiana.
Robert E. Gates, The Farmers Loan and Trust Company Building, Columbia City, Indiana.
Joseph Christoff, 617 Gettle Building, Fort Wayne, Indiana.

div.head: Law Alumni President Extends Greetings
div.p: FELLOW ALUMNI:

We want you to meet our new baby, christened The I-Witness and launched with great hope that it will tie us closer together, give us more news of each other, increase our membership, help with our scholarship, placement, and recruitment programs, and serve Indiana University better.
While it will be published with the help of students, its primary purpose is for the graduates and for the Alumni Association.
We hope you will enjoy reading it, and that you will help by sending in news items about our lawyers in your community.

div.head: BAR RESULTS
div.p: All Indiana University law school graduates who took the Indiana bar examination this March passed successfully. Congratulations to the new barristers.

div.head: Prominent U. of Chicago Law Professor Speaks At Law Journal Banquet
div.p: Karl Llewellyn delivered a speech on "Your Profession at Home" to the staff their wives, alumni, and other guests on March 21 at the Van Orman Hotel.

Mr. Llewellyn is Professor of Law at the University of Chicago. His major fields of interest are commercial law and jurisprudence in both of which he excels. He has been a draftsman of various uniform commercial acts and is co-author of The Cheyenne Way, a work basic to any study of primitive law.

Professor Llewellyn emphasized the intangible benefits accruing to lawyers and discussed the responsibilities of lawyers in non-legal capacities. He illustrated the craftsmanship of attorneys by using an example of how various conflicting interests are resolved in a family situation.

Approximately ninety persons attended the banquet which is the annual highlight of Journal activities. Bob Miser Senior Associate in charge of note topic, research, served as general chairman of the banquet.

div.head: OVER 200 HEAR HALLECK SPEAK AT LAW DAY BANQUET, MAY 1
div.p: The Honorable Charles A. Halleck, LL.B. '24, keynoted the annual Law Day sponsored by the Law Club in connection with national commemoration of that day.

Activities for the "day" included Mr. Byron Kennedy 's speech the evening before, the freshman-upper classmen softball game, moot court competition and the banquet at the Van Orman-Graham Hotel. The banquet featured awards to outstanding students and presentation of the Gavel Award and was highlighted by Representative Halleck's speech.

Judge James A. Emmert, former Indiana Supreme Court Judge, introduced Representative Halleck. Representative Halleck departed from his prepared speech on "The Problem of Federal Preemption" and delivered instead a more informal address dealing with current political problems and more light-hearted reminiscences of his collegiate days here at Indiana University. Federal preemption was mentioned however, with Representative Halleck declaring that courts should find such preemption only when Congress has made its intent to preempt clear, and that Congress has the duty to enact new legislation when it feels the courts have misinterpreted its intent.
The banquet was attended by about 200 honored guests, faculty members, students, wives and dates.
As a prelude to Law Day activities, Mr. Byron C. Kennedy of Rockhill, Vanderveer, Kennedy and Lee of Warsaw, Indianaspoke to students April 30 on specific ethical problems confronting attorneys.

Mr. Kennedy was elected Judge of the Wabash circuit court when he was twenty- seven, and served fifteen years. He has been associated with his present firm since 1956. He is a 1928 graduate of the Indiana Law School, now the Indianapolis Division of the School of Law.

div.head: News Of The Law Journal
div.p: The editorial staff of the Indiana Law Journal for the academic year consisted of Marvin L. Hackman, Editor in Chief; Virgil L. Beeler, Article and Book Review Editor; and John Backus, James Haramy, Richard McIntire, and William Stewart, Note Editors. The student writing staff was composed of three seniors and ten juniors.

Beginning with the current volume, the Journal will be supported by subscriptions and a subsidy by the University. Its former sponsor, the Indiana State Bar Association, has discontinued its support. A subscription should be sent to the Business Manager, Indiana Law Journal, School of Law, Bloomington, Indiana.

div.head: INDIANAPOLIS WINS

figure.p: James Fitzpatrick Argues Before Indiana Appellate Court

div.p: The Indianapolis Division won the annual Law Day Moot Court competition between the Bloomington and Indianapolis Divisions. The Indiana Appellate Court sat as judges for the occasion.

This year's problem stemmed from a tort suit against an insurance company in Alabama. An aunt with no insurable interest took out insurance policies on her two year old niece. The aunt then put arsenic in a coke she served her niece,from which the little girl died. Her father sued the insurance company for neg- ligently issuing a policy to one with no insurable interest, obtaining a judgment for $75,000. The primary issue concerned the applicability of the contract rule of insurable interest in the field of torts.
The appellants for the insurance company were Messrs. Fitzpatrick and Owens of the Bloomington Division. Messrs. Rhoads and DeTrude of the Indianapolis Division argued for the appellee father.

div.head: Harris lectures Feature Outstanding American And English Law Professors
div.p: Comparative Law was the theme of this year's Addison C. Harris Memorial Lectures. The lecture series is made possible through the generosity of Mrs. Harris who established the fund in memory of her husband, a prominent practitioner in Indiana.

Frederick H. Lawson, Barrister (Gray's Inn) and Professor of Comparative Law at Oxford Universitywas the initial speaker; his topic was "The Approach to French Law." Professor Lawson is currently Visiting Professor at the University of Pensylvania.

"The Approach to German Law" was delivered by Max Rheinstein, Max Pam Professor of Comparative Law at the University of Chicago. He is a member of the International Academy of Comparative Law and the German Society of Comparative Law.

A "Comparison of Soviet and American Law" was the subject of Professor Harold J. Berman, the third speaker in the series. He has been a member of the Research Association, Russian Research Center, Harvard since 1948. Professor Berman recently argued a royalty case in the Soviet Union for Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's son, which was dismissed, but which may be appealed next August.
The last lecture of the series, "The Comparative Method in the Common Law," was delivered by Professor Ronald H. Graveson, Barrister (Gray's Inn), and Professor of Law at the University of London.

Professor Gravesonis Dean, Faculty of Law, King's College, London. He also serves as Chairman of the United Kingdom National Committee of Comparative Law. Professor Graveson is Visiting Professor at Harvard this year.

The lectures this year were held in the Moot Court Room of the Law Building at Bloomington and were arranged by a committee composed of the following faculty members: Professors Clifford, Hall and Rutledge of the Bloomington Division, and Professors Foust and Mandelker of the Indianapolis Division. Informal receptions in the Common Rooms of the Law Building followed each lecture.

div.head: SUMMER EMPLOYMENT
div.p: A number of law firms and corporate legal offices are employing students for the summer between the students' second and third years in law school. This plan enables both the employer and student to evaluate one another and determine whether a post-graduation association would be desirable. While the idea began with larger offices it is now becoming popular with smaller firms as well.

figure.head: Professor F. Reed Dickerson Meets Seminar

div.p: Mr. F. Reed Dickerson was appointed as Professor of Law at the Bloomington Division last fall. His courses include Legislation, Seminar in Legislation, Seminar in Land Use Controls, and Commercial Law.
He received his LL.B from Harvard in 1934. In 1938,he enrolled in Columbia where he obtained his LL.M.; he received his J.S.D. from the same school in 1950.

Prof. Dickerson's teaching career began in 1938 as a lecturer at Northwestern University. Washington University at St. Louis then named him assistant professor. He next moved to the University of Pittsburgh in the same capacity until 1942. He also lectured at American University in 1956 and 1958.

The government obtained his services in 1942 when he served as director of pricing standards for the OPA until 1947. He served as assistant legal counsel to the House of Representatives for the next two years. He then became deputy chief and chairman of the commission on codification for the Joint Army-Air Force Statutory Revision Group, Department of Defense, until 1956. He was assistant to the general counsel and deputy assistant general counsel dealing with codification until 1958, when he came to Indiana, having been in charge of the codification of Titles 10 and 32 of the U.S. Code.

Mr. Dickerson received the distinguished civilian service award from the Department of Defense in 1957. He is a member of the American Law Institute National Legislative Conference. Governor Handley has recently appointed him as an Indiana Commissioner on Uniform State Laws. Books published by Professor Dickerson include Products Liability and the Food Consumer and Legislative Drafting.

div.head: Bloomington Division Professors Contribute To Written Legal Scholarship
div.p: Distinguished Service Professor Jerome Hall's most recent book is Studies in Jurisprudence and Criminal Theory published by Oceana .This book was the subject of an article by Associate Professor Gerhard O. W. Meuller, Director of Comparative Criminal Law Project, New York University School of Law, printed in 34 Indiana Law Journal at page 206. The University of Buffalo has published his lectures on "Reason and Reality in Jurisprudence" which were given as its Mitchell Lecture Series. Professor Hall's debates at Harvard on "Mental Disease and Criminal Responsibility" appear in 33 Indiana Law Journal 212. The North Dakota Law Review of October, 1958 carries his article A Law Teacher's Tour Around the World."
Professor Ivan Rutledge 's book review appears in 34 Indiana Law Journalat page 138. His review was of Studies in Jurisprudence: V. Free Man Versus His Government, edited by Arthur L. Harding.

Professor F. Reed Dickerson has an article soon to appear in the Rutgers Law Review on "Group Interests in the Field of Food Law." Volume 44of the ABA Journal contains his "Legislative Drafting: American and British Practices Compared". The same article is to be printed by the Cambridge Law Journal.

Assistant Professor Maurice Kirk has completed his Second Report to the Governor and General Assembly of Indiana on the Codification of the Indiana Common School Laws, which was published in November, 1958.
Professor Ralph Fuchs' address to the Association of American Law Schools,The Proposed New Code of Administrative Procedure has been printed by the Ohio State Law Journal in volume 19, page 423.
Professor John Bauman's article submitted to Columbia University toward his doctorate has been printed in 33 Indiana Law Journal 467. His work isA Rationale of Summary Judgment
Associate Professor W. Howard Mann's book review of Essays on Constitutional Law has been published in the Journal of Legal Education.

div.head: Rutledge Receives Gavel Award At Law Day Ceremony
div.p: Each year the Senior class presents the Gavel Award to the non-student who has made the greatest contribution to the development of that class. Professor Ivan Rutledge received that distinction this year.

Mr. Rutledge has taught Administrative Law, Antitrust Law, Constitutional Law, Federal Jurisdiction, Trade Regulation, Criminal Law, International Law, Labor Law, Legal Writing, and Trail and Appellate Practice. Professor Rutledge's analytical approach and emphasis on use of legal principles and tools is perhaps his greatest contribution to our class, although his ability to correlate specific problems to their broader perspectives is no less important.

Previous Gavel Award recipients include John S. Hastings in 1948 and in the following years, C. Ben Dutton, Jr., Bernard Gavit, Alfred Evens, Miss Margaret Greene, Jerome Hall, Frank E. Horack, Jr., Leon Wallace, Herman Krannert, Miss Betty LeBus, and Austin V. Clifford.

div.head: Bloomington Division Offers New Course For Third Year Students
div.p: A course in trial techniques has been added as a part of the Legal Techniques program inaugurated in 1956. The freshman course involves legal research and drafting problems. Second year students have the traditional appellate level moot court problem as well as other problems. This year the project was the drafting of articles of incorporation from a prior partnership in which one partner had deceased. The seniors this year have been assigned problems dealing with pre-trial and trial steps in advocacy. Problems from pleading to fact investigation to cross examination and motions for instructions have been included to help bridge the gap between student education and actual problems encountered.

The trial tactics program is under the direction of Professor Austin V. Clifford who practiced in Indiana and Chicago from 1922 to 1942. He served in the Army as a Captain and Major from 1942 until 1946 working with refugee and displaced per- sons' problems. He was with the prosecution in the 9th Army black market cases. Mr. Clifford has been a professor since 1946. He is assisted by Daniel Rotenberg who was in the Air Force JAG and by Frederick Franklin who was in the Attorney General's Honor Recruitment Program for two years, both Teaching Associates. The Legal Techniques program is made possible through the generosity of the Inland Container Corporation Foundation, Inc., established by Mr. Herman C. Krannert.

div.head: BloomingtonDivision Law Club And Fraternities Have Busy Year
div.p: Under the guiding hands of Andrew Hays, President; Chad Songer, Vice President; Gene Pride, Secretary; Fred Bauer, Treasurer, and Bill Salin, Senior Member at Large, the Law Club of the Bloomington Division presented a varied program of extra curricular activities for the much welcome "free time" of the students.

A new activity inaugurated this year was the sponsorship of coffee hours at which various persons prominent in the university spoke. Among the speakers was Herman B Wells, President of the University. President Wells related his experiences as a delegate to the United Nations. Professor F. Reed Dickerson discussed at another meeting "The Role of the Lawyer in the Department of Defense."

Athletic activities included the undefeated, un-scored on season of the "Pogo Pups" in the Independent League in football. Since the Medical School has moved to Indianapolis the traditional Law-Medic football game at Homecoming time has been discontinued. Intramural champions Sigma Nu substituted for the Medical School and were trounced by 6-0 on the strength of Pete Obremskey's touchdown.

The Law-Med boress was also cancelled but the Laws participated in Homecoming by initiating the Law Walk with canes and derbies and were provided a special section in the stadium for students, wives, and dates. The laws also won the Independent League championship in basketball.
Other fall activities included the traditional stag party at the Policemen's Lodge and the Fall Dance at the Van Orman Suburban. The Spring Law Dance was held at the Sarkes Tarzian Ballroom.
Besides sponsoring the previously noted activities of Law Day, the Law Club promotes the annual freshman-upper classmen softball game which was won this year by the upper classmen.

div.head: Phi Delta Phi
div.p: During the heat of last fall's elections Phi Delta Phi presented as evening speakers Judge Donald E. Bowen, who advocated the Republican point of view, and Senator Matthew E. Welsh, who countered with the Democratic viewpoint.

The monthly informal luncheon program was once again a success and attracted the following speakers: Wilbur Stevens, I.U. Backfield Coach; Assistant Professor James E. Culbertson of the Speech Department; Roy Harris, Resident Composer in the School of Music; Assistant Professor John T. Liell of the Sociology Department; Associate Professor Fred Witney of the Department of Economics; and Wardell B. Pomeroy, Research Associate, and Instructor in the Institute for Sex Research.
The Spring Banquet, featured Mr. Roger Branigin, prominent Indiana lawyer and politician, as speaker. The rush smoker held in the Faculty Lounge resulted in a pledge class of 45 persons.
Officers for the second semester are Max Hobbs, Magister; Jerry Newman, Exchequer; Philip Siegel, Clerk; and Jim Droege, Historian.

div.head: Delta Theta Phi
div.p: Formal initiation of 23 pledges occured on December 3, 1958. This was followed by a rush smoker on March 3, 1959, as a result of which 20 men were pledged. An informal "Pseudo Ski Party" in honor of the pledge class was held at the Policeman's Lodge on March 14 to which wives and dates were also invited.
Future plans include a post final exam celebration and a softball game if Phi Delta Phi accepts the challenge offered. Plans are also underway to inaugurate an annual formal initiation banquet.

This year's activities were supervised by John Cutshaw, Dean; Ted Miller, Vice-Dean; Jack O'Drobinak, Tribune; Gene Pride, Clerk of Rolls; Phil Brown, Clerk of Exchequer; Jerry Hyland, Master of Ritual; and George Rich, Bailiff.

div.head: Chicago Area Law School Alumni Hold Luncheon Meetings
div.p: April 29 marked the third luncheon gathering of Indiana University law school alumni living in the Chicago Area. The meeting was attended by Frank Jones, Assistant Alumni Secretary, and Richard Quaintance, Assistant Dean of the School of Law.
Earlier meetings were held on March 18, and last December 30. The December meeting was attended by Dean Wallace and several members of the law school faculty.
Future meetings are being planned. For information contact Richard S. Rhodes, '53 at Randolph 6-2545.

div.head: Virgil Beeler Wins Phi Delta Phi Scholarship Trophy
div.p: The annual Phi Delta Phi Scholastic Trophy for the senior with highest grades was awarded to Mr. Virgil Beeler. Virgil finished his undergraduate work at Indiana in the Economics Department in 1953 and then spent two years in the U.S. Army, including a tour of duty in Europe. After this he enrolled in Law School, winning Krannert, Willkie and Edwards Scholarships. This year Virgil served as Article and Book Review editor for the Indiana Law Journal.
Virgil, his wife Jeanette, and their two sons plan to move to Indianapolis where he will be associated with the firm of Baker and Daniels. Warning to golfers- he shoots in the low 80's.
Richard C. Quaintance, an alumnus of Indiana University and former head of a retail promotion service firm in Chicago has been named assistant dean of the Indiana University School of Law.
Since his appointment last September, Dean Quaintance has divided his time between developing an active placement service for the benefit of students and alumni, and promoting alumni affairs.
The new assistant dean received the bachelor of science degree in business administration from Indiana in 1948 and the law degree last June.

div.head: News Of Bloomington Division Faculty Here And There
div.p: Professor Ralph Fuchs will be teaching in Salzburg, Austria, in the Seminar in American Studies. His course in Administrative Law will be of four weeks duration.
Associate Professor William Oliver is going to practice in Chicago this summer and will be associated with Sidley, Austin, Burgess and Smith.
Professor Val Nolan Jr. has returned from his leave of absence which he spent working on a study of the marketability of land titles and pursuing his ornithological studies.
Assistant Professor Maurice Kirk will return to teaching duties this summer after having finished his work on school law codification.
Professor John Bauman and Associate Professor Pratter are both on sabbatical leaves, Professor Bauman for the second semester and Professor Pratter for the school year.
Professor Bauman is Visiting Professor at U.C.L.A. Professor Pratter is working on a jurisprudential article and has lectured at Columbia University Law School.

div.head: News of Indianapolis Division - Faculty, Students, Alumni
div.p: Dean Henry B. Witham was recently elected Secretary-Treasurer of the Indiana Bar Foundation. He has completed a revision of Witham, Selected Cases on Contracts Remedies With References to the Restatement of Contracts.

Professor Cleon H. Foust was appointed by Governor Harold W. Handley to the Study Commission on Forensic Sciences. His Bill No. 381, "To Create a State Commission on Forensic Sciences," was passed in the 1959 state legislature. Professor Foust also co-authored an article for the current Indiana State Medical Journal- "Some Medico-legal Aspects of Blood Extraction." In the April issue of Res Gestae appears his The Lawyer and the New Forensic Science Legislation in Indiana". To be issued in book form is Professor Foust's Symposium on Alcohol and Road Traffic at Indiana University-"The Implied Consent Laws."

Professor John S. Grimes has just received from Bobbs-Merrill the 3rd and 9th Volumes of his revision of Thompson on Real Property and IIIA was just released. He completed and published biennial supplements to Thompson on Property, Thompson on Wills and Henry's Indiana Probate Law. At present he is completing work on the Law of Surveying and Boundaries based on Clark on Surveying and revision of Thompson, Volume IV is now in process.

Professor Lester B. Orfield was on sabbatical leave the first semester 1958-59 and did research work in the Scandinavian countries. He also lectured at the Universities of Lund and Stockholm. He was granted a $1500 award by the Social Science Research Commission of New York City for a study of health insurance laws of the Scandinavian countries.

Professor Ben F. Small is still flying each Monday to and from Washington University at St. Louis, Missouri,to teach "Constitutional Law." The assignment was for the past and present semesters. He was named by Indiana's Governor Handley as an Indiana Commissioner of Uniform State Laws, and was elected this spring to membership in the American Academy of Forensic Sciences. He recently completed the 1958 Supplement to Small's Workmen's Compensation Law Of Indiana; Chapter 1 on "Causation" in Moritz & Helberg's book, Trauma and Disease, and "The Heart Problem in Workmen's Compensation," Journal of the Indiana State Medical Association for February, 1959.
Professor R. Bruce Townsend is currently revising the casebook materials for his course, "Commercial Law," which was added to the curriculum and taught the first semester, 1958-59.

Associate Professor Daniel R. Mandelker will begin his sabbatical leave in September. He has been awarded a Ford Foundation grant which will extend his leave through the Second Semester, 1959-60. He and his family will reside in London, England, where he will undertake a study of the administrative operation of English planning law governing development of land and control of land use.

Assistant Professor Charles D. Kelso is presently on sabbatical leave in Miami, Florida, University of Miami, doing research for future publications. He has the following works on the presses: Washington University Law Quarterly, "The Process of Analyzing a Conflict of Laws Case"; an article as part of a symposium in the Minnesota Law Review, Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support: 1958 Dimensions," and a book review of the Read-MacDonald Casebook on Legislation in the Journal of Legal Education.

div.head: Student Activities
div.p: The Law Club at the Indianapolis Division has this year been working on an apprenticeship program for students in that division. The basic purpose of this program is to provide students with employment in law offices or in fields closely related to the law. Through this plan, it is hoped thai students will gain familiarity with the practical problems they will face upon graduation. The Law Club's activities in this field are being handled by a committee under the direction of Norman Kassenbrock. The work is being coordinated with the division's present placement service. In the very near future a brochure describing the plan will be circulated to law firms and selected businesses in the Indianapolis area. It is hoped that all of our graduates will feel free to contact the committee or Dick Bodine, president of the Law Club, in regard to possibilities of employment or any other suggestions they might have.
Winners of the Merchants National Bank and Trust Co. will-drafting contest were William D. Hall, Norman Newman,John Skinner, and John Rhoads.
The Phi Delta Phi senior award was given to Richard Bodine.
The U. S. Law Week Award for the senior making most satisfactory scholastic progress was won by Fred G. Thelander .

Robert C. Wilson had his note "Insuring Risk Loss Under Land Purchase Contract" printed in the November-December 1958 issue of Res Gestae. William King has contributed material from "Use of Mob Violence Statutes as a Remedy in the Protection of Civil Rights" for use in an article for the Race Relations Law Reporter.

Sigma Delta Kappa sponsored a federal pre-trial conference; Dale Palmer served as chairman. Participants were Erle A. Kightlinger, Howard Young,Arthur Paine, Claud Spilman and R. Stanley Lawton. The success of the conference has led to plans to continue it as a regular program.

div.head: RECENT I-DIVISION GRADUATES IN POLITICAL, GOVERNMENTAL JOBS
div.p: Robert J. Find '52 is Executive Secretary to Governor Harold Handley.
Karl Kolger '57 serves as city attorney in Wayne County.
Richard J. Groover '51 has been appointed as circuit judge for Henry County by Governor Handley.
Lehman Sadler '54 is with the Indiana Securities Commission.
Robert S. Webb '48 is chairman of the Indiana Public Service Commission.
John C. Vandivier, Jr., '56 is Assistant United States Attorney General.
Russell A. Sorenson '57 is Special Assistant Attorney General in St. Paul, Minn.
Richard M. Gwan '51 is an Assistant Attorney General for the State of Indiana.
Richard E. Aikman '55 is with the Appellate Division of the Internal Revenue.
Joseph Hadley '51 is Hearing Judge of the Alcohol Beverage Commission.
George E. Marty '57 is Public Defender for Marion County.
John Dillon '52 is Marion County City Attorney.
Miss Joan Caldwell '57 is counsel for for the Metropolitan Planning Commission.
David L. Millen '55 is Attorney-Examiner for the Indiana Public Service Commission.
Serving in the Indiana House of Representatives are Andrew Jacobs, Jr. '58 and Miss Marie T. Lauch '55. Indiana Senate members include John Ruckelshaus '57 and Ruel Steele '48.
David D. Finney '53 is Marion County Assessor.

Judges include Everett N. Lucas '49, Clinton County; Milford Anness '54 Fayette County; Austin Childress '54 Owen County; M. Walter Bell '52 Marion County Superior Court No. 1; Robert G. Robb '49, Marion County Superior Court No. 3; Richard M. Salb '50, Division No. 1, Criminal Court; Ernie S. Burke '52 Municipal Court No. 3; Charles Daugherty '53 Municipal Court No. 4; John C. Christ '51 Municipal Court No. 5; and Noble R. Pearcy'51, Municipal Court No. 6.

Frank E. Russell '51 is Control Division Manager and Executive Vice President of Spickelnier Industries. Frank A. Steldt '49 is with the patent department of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co. at Minneapolis.
Peter Martin Witham '58 is with the army JAG, Camp Campbell, Kentucky.William R. Pritchard '58 is Science Department Head of the University of Florida, Gainesville.
Paul E. Rawley '57 is Assistant Trust Officer of Merchants Bank and Trust Co. Jack M. Schenck '55 is in the same department.
Richard M. Huston '51 is Secretary and General Counsel of the Indianapolis Legal Aid. His professional staff members are Leroy Frieherr '57, John Hammond '57, and Bruce Nelson '57.

div.head: Bloomington Division Graduates Accept Varied Positions in Government, Corporations, Private Practice, and Service
div.p: This year's class members have taken a wide variety of jobs in many different locations. For those of you who may be looking for prospective associates, there are still several capable students who have not yet accepted jobs.

div.head: Graduates Entering Government Work
div.p: Marvin Hackman will serve as law clerk to JudgeSteckler of the Federal District Court sitting in Indianapolis. His appointment is for a two-year term.
James Fitzpatrick will also serve a two-year term as law clerk. His appointment is with Judge John S. Hastings, soon to be Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Federal Circuit.

div.head: Corporations Tap Law Grads
div.p: Jon Bulkley has accepted a position with the Finance Department of the Ford Motor Co. and will live in Detroit following graduation.
Andy Hays will be with the industrial relations staff of Kennecott Copper at their Salt Lake City office.
John Waggoner will also be in industrial relations. His job is with the Trane Co. in La Crosse, Wisconsin.

div.head: Trust Departments
div.p: Ron Baker is working in Indianapolis with the trust department of the Merchant's National Bank and Trust .
Al Weber will be moving to Sarasota, Florida in a similar capacity with Palmer First National Bank and Trust Co.

div.head: With the University
div.p: Hilliard Trubitt is Director of Research for the Center for Police Training at Indiana University.
Barry Jellison will remain at the Law School as a Teaching Associate with the Legal Techniques program.

div.head: What? Me Worry?
div.p: The following men found job hunting easy; they are all going to associated with their fathers: Fred Bauer, Ed Grimm, Millard Morrill Morrison, John Sweeney, Jack Rogers, Phil Potts, Jordan Lewis, and Gene Chipman. Spencer Schnaitter will be associated with Harold Ford, his father's associate. His father now serves as judge.

div.head: With Firms in Large Cities
div.p: Virgil Beeler has accepted a job with Baker and Daniels of Indianapolis.
Dick McIntire will be moving to Washington, D.C. where he will be associated with Covington and Burling.
Terry Dietsch is returning to Evansvillewhere he will work with Ortmeyer, Bamberger, Ortmeyer and Foreman.
Bob Miser is associated with the Wall Street firm of Cahill, Gordon, Reindel, and Ohl.
Hal Sanford has accepted a job with Nicholson, Nisen and Elliott in Chicago .
Phil Smith will be located in Minneapolis with Merchant and Merchant.

div.head: With Firms in Medium Size Cities
div.p: George Tripp has moved to Richmond where he is associated with Griffis, Griffis and Cox.
Verl Miller is in Terre Haute with Rosenfeld and Wolfe.
Dan Connell has located in South Bend where he is associated with Voor, Jackson and McMichael.
Ken Fedder will move back to Michigan City where he will be associated with his uncle.
Dick Good will be with Jump, Noel and Lacey in Kokomo.
Sam Reed has accepted a job in Muncie with Bracken, DeFur, Voran and Hanley.
Len Malech will be associated with Henry J. Bendheim in Englewood, N. J.
Jim Jordan has accepted a job with Archie Lapin in Muncie.

div.head: In Smaller Towns
div.p: John Backus is associated with Karl L. Chattin of Goshen.
George Wildman has moved to Shelbyville where he is associated with Pell and Macthett.
Lyle Strahan is practicing in Montfort, Wisconsin.
Dick Bray is Prosecuting Attorney in Martinsville.
Mac Campbell is going to Winchester where he will be associated with Mendenhall, Hunter and Stohler.
Bill Garrard has accepted a job with Graham, Rasor, Eschbach and Harris of Warsaw.
George Languell is Prosecuting Attorney in Owen County.
Stan Matheny has affiliated with H. Harold Soshnick of Shelbyville.
Bill Seese will be in Bluffton with Galivan and Hamilton.
Marty Weissert is moving to Plymouth where he will be employed by Stevens and Wampler.
Bill Salinwill move to Kendallville where he will be associated with FinleyWyman.

div.head: Last of a Vanishing Breed
div.p: Doug Owens is the only senior who is bold enough to hang out his single by himself. He is returning to his home town of Pendleton.

div.head: Miscellaneous
div.p: LaMar Worley is in Crown Point with the Calumet Title Co.
Jack Gunter has moved to Midland, Texas where he works for the Texas Co.
Tom Reeder will be with Lawyers Title Insurance at Miami, Florida.
Leonard Tompkins has accepted a job with the State Farm Mutual Insurance Co.

div.head: Uncle Sam Takes His Toll
div.p: Jerry Crowell, Bill Andrews, Fred Bauer, Jack Chevigny, Jim Droege, Dave Keck, Marc Lansky, Ralph Martin, Al Teagle, Conrad Harvey, and Bill McCrae, all have a tour of duty with the armed services on schedule after graduation.
